name: 02-Data Preparation
content:
Data Description:

This dataset is designed for predicting diabetes in patients based on various medical and physiological attributes. The classification goal is to determine the likelihood of diabetes presence to support early intervention and healthcare decision-making. The dataset includes the following columns:

  • Pregnancies: Number of times pregnant - an integer value indicating pregnancy history.
  • Glucose: Plasma glucose concentration over 2 hours in an oral glucose tolerance test (mg/dL).
  • BloodPressure: Diastolic blood pressure measurement (mm Hg).
  • SkinThickness: Triceps skin fold thickness (mm) - a measure of body fat.
  • Insulin: 2-Hour serum insulin level (mu U/ml).
  • BMI: Body Mass Index - weight in kg/(height in m)Â² - a measure of body fat based on height and weight.
  • DiabetesPedigreeFunction: A function scoring likelihood of diabetes based on family history.
  • Age: Age of the patient in years.
  • Outcome: Target variable (0 or 1) indicating absence or presence of diabetes.

Data Preparation:

1. Data Cleaning:

  • Handle Missing Values:
  • Identify and address zero values in Glucose, BloodPressure, SkinThickness, Insulin, and BMI as these are likely missing data placeholders
  • Apply appropriate imputation strategies based on feature distributions
  • Outlier Detection:
  • Identify and handle outliers in numerical features using statistical methods
  • Pay special attention to extreme values in Glucose, BMI, and Insulin measurements

2. Feature Engineering: Compute Additional Features:

  • Age_Group: Categorize patients into meaningful age ranges (e.g., Young Adult, Middle-Aged, Senior)
  • BMI_Category: Classify BMI into standard categories (Underweight, Normal, Overweight, Obese)
  • Glucose_Category: Group glucose levels into classifications (Normal, Prediabetic, Diabetic)
  • BP_Category: Categorize blood pressure readings (Normal, Elevated, High)
  • Insulin_Category: Group insulin levels (Normal, Low, High)
  • Pregnancy_Group: Categorize number of pregnancies (None, Low, Moderate, High)
  • DPF_Category: Group Diabetes Pedigree Function into risk levels (Low, Medium, High genetic risk)

3. Data Transformation:

  • Feature Scaling:
  • Apply standardization or normalization to numerical features
  • Ensure all features contribute equally to the Random Forest model
  • Categorical Encoding:
  • Convert engineered categorical features into numerical format
  • Use appropriate encoding methods (One-Hot Encoding or Label Encoding)

4. Data Validation:

  • Range Checks: Ensure all values fall within medically reasonable ranges
  • Correlation Analysis: Identify and address highly correlated features
  • Distribution Analysis: Examine feature distributions and handle any significant skewness
  • Class Balance: Assess and address any class imbalance in the target variable
